bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, October 31, 1942

div1.p: Kean has been notified that he is to receive the Gorgas Medal for several accomplishments early in his career, including starting warfare on the mosquito in Cuba, initiating the legislation that created the Medical Reserve Corps, and for organizing the Base Hospitals in parent institutions.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, October 31, 1942
div1.opener:
ans 12/13/42
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
October 31st 42
My dear Colonel Hench
div1.p:
It has been a month and a
week since I had that fine long
letter from you and I cannot let
this month go by without a request
for news. So many things may
happen in a month in war time!
I had an idea that Mr. Kellogg
told you, when he was in Denver
and saw you and Mrs. Hench at
dinner, of the wonderful surprise
that he and Col. Hume had in
store for me - the Gorgas medal
with a fine fat prize of $50000 for
work done long ago. In the letter
of notification which came from
AC
K
2
the Sec'y of the Assn of Military Surgeons
(of which I hope you are now a member) Col.
Phalen, on Oct. 15, he said it was
awarded to me and to two others “for dis-
tinguished services in preventive medicine
for our armed forces”. I have not
yet seen what was enumerated in
the formal citation, but understood
from Col. Hume that it would include
initiating the warfare against the
mosquito in Cuba in October 1900, for
initiating the legislation to create the
Medical Reserve Corps in 1904 and for
organizing the Base Hospitals in parent
institutions in 1916. I think that the
creation of the Medical Reserve Corps
was my best job. It took a long, hard
3
fight of 4 years to get it past the
General Staff and through Congress.
It became a law in 1908. The Navy M.C.
imitated it the next year and in eight
years more the General had learned
that it would be a wonderful agency
for expansion for war and they adopt-
ed it for the entire army -(in 1916)
The Rip Van Winkle sleep of the Gorgas
medal for 26 years after its creation in
1916 is a curious and long story. I
will not go into it unless I hear that
Mr. Kellogg did not tell it to you
as an after - dinner story, and that
you are interested to hear it.

From the intermission in your
correspondent I feel sure that you
are very busy and that you have
4
not been able to secure a fine capable
WAAC to be your stenog. & secretary-like
the Secy at Rochester whom you miss so
much. I had a visit from General Ireland
yesterday and he inquired if there was
any news of you. He had just returned
from Louisville,Ky. where was a meeting
of the Nat. Med. Exam. Board. Today he
goes to New York to some medical meet-
ing in which the A. M. A. is interested.
They keep him busy with jobs, in which
he has only the reward of a good conscience

I realize perfectly what little time you
have for letter writing, but a single page, or
even a plebean postal is much better
than nothing. The fight in the Solomons
keeps us all anxious as doubtless it does you.

closer.salute: With cordial regards your friend sincerely
